The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of thepast week.Bomber Command had carried out a successful raid onStuttgart. Turin had been attacked twice. Coastal Command had attacked one U-boat and a number of enemy vessels, including a blockade-runner. Fighter Command had flown 700 offensive sortiesbesides sorties on shipping protection. In the Home Theatre theenemy had lost 8 aircraft destroyed and 4 probably destroyed. our losses had been 6 fighters (1 pilot safe), 18 bombers and 4 coastal command aircraft.United States aircraft had attacked the Biscay submarine bases and caused disorganisation.Aircraft based on Gibraltar had made 7 promising attacks onU-boats. In North-West Africa 41 enemy aircraft had been destroyed, 7 probably destroyed and 24 damaged. Our losses hadbeen 16 aircraft destroyed and 7 damaged.Aircraft based on Malta had attacked aerodromes in Sicily andTunis, and air-borne supply lines to Tunisia.In Cyrenaica, despite bad weather, our aircraft had continuedto harass the enemy retreat. Forty-two enemy aircraft had been destroyed, 3 probably destroyed and 43 damaged. We had lost24 aircraft.Merchant shipping losses for the previous week amounted to129,000 tons.Of the 10 ships, independently routed, 5 had now arrived in north Russia. The others had been lost.An Indian Naval minesweeper escorting a tanker from australia to India had been attacked by 2 Japanese raiders. after a gallant action on the part of both our ships, one of the raiders hadbeen sunk and the other had turned away. Both the minesweeperand the tanker (the latter having been torpedoed) had reached port.Suitable rewards for this action were under consideration.A west-bound convoy had reached Malta. The merchant vesselsarrived safely. One escorting cruiser had been torpedoed but had reached port.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff undertook toascertain whether any orders had been given for anincrease in the rations for troops at Malta.In the recent naval battle fought by night between UnitedStates and Japanese forces the Japanese had probably lost 2 battle-ships, 6 heavy cruisers and a number of destroyers. Of 12 Japanesetransports, 8 had been sunk and 4 beached and later destroyed. TheJapanese thereby might well have lost some 20,000 men. UnitedStates losses included 2 light cruisers.A case had occurred in which the new net protection had successfully detonated an enemy torpedo without damage to the ship.The First Sea Lord was asked to make proposals to the anti-U-Boat Warfare Committee as to acceleration of the programmes for manufacturing and fitting these nets.The enemy was endeavouring to spread southwards from his main lodgment in Bizerta and Tunis, and much depended on the speed with which we could bring up our forces to counter this move.Attention was drawn to a report that Bizerta Harbour was full of enemy transports, and the importance of attacking them, was stressed. .The Chief of the Air Staff undertook to inform the PrimeMinister of the action which aircraft, based on Malta, were taking to this end.In Cyrenaica operations had been impeded by bad weather,which had limited our pursuit mainly to the roads, where progress had been relatively slow because, of craters and enemy mines. TheWar Cabinet were informed of the present disposition of the eighth Army, and Of the enemy forces likely to be available. Ourproblem was now primarily one of overcoming the administrative difficulties of maintaining a force so far ahead of its base. Russia. The Russians had launched two counter-attacks to the northand south of Stalingrad; and there were indications that the one from the south was making good progress and had reached the Don.This pincer movement had great possibilities.In the south, Russian counter-attacks seemed to have secured the Georgian Pass.The War Cabinet took note of these statements.2.
